questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to AIIMS OPD with complaints of oligomenorrhea for the past six months. She has a history of two previous pregnancies, both of which resulted in miscarriages. She underwent an HSG which is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) GU TB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salpingitis isthmica nodosa seen on HSG is a classic manifestation of genitourinary tuberculosis (GU TB) , characterized by nodular outpouchings in the fallopian tubes, and can be associated with infertility and menstrual irregularities.

questions.text: A patient is brought to casualty and a whole-body CT scan has to be done. This CT scan will include the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CT Limbs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a whole-body CT scan, limbs are not routinely included unless there is specific evidence or suspicion of injury to those areas.
  • ➤ limbs are not routinely included

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a history of blurred vision and eye pain in her left eye for the past few months. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes a pigmented lesion on the iris with irregular borders and a raised appearance. The pupil is slightly distorted, and there is mild dilation of the pupil. The intraocular pressure is within normal limits. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A T1 weighted MRI is shown here. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Melanoma

questions.text: Match the following :
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus

questions.text: Who is recognized for the discovery of the gamma knife?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lars Leksell

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Felix Block & Purcell are notable for their contribution to the development of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), not the gamma knife.
  • • Option A:
  • • Felix Block & Purcell
  • • development of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance
  • • Option B: Henry Becquerel is acknowledged as the Father of Radioactivity.
  • • Option B:
  • • Henry Becquerel
  • • Father of Radioactivity.
  • • Option D: WC Roentgen is celebrated as the Father of Radiology and the discoverer of X-rays, which are different from the gamma rays utilized in the gamma knife technology.
  • • Option D:
  • • WC Roentgen
  • • Father of Radiology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lars Leksell is recognized for the discovery of the gamma knife , a significant advancement in the precise treatment of brain conditions using targeted radiation therapy .
  • ➤ Lars Leksell
  • ➤ discovery of the gamma knife
  • ➤ treatment of brain conditions
  • ➤ targeted radiation therapy

questions.text: In diagnostic radiography, Photoelectric effect can be best described as an:

options.label: A
options.text: Interaction between low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron

options.label: B
options.text: Interaction between high energy incident photon and the inner shell electron

options.label: C
options.text: Interaction between low energy incident photon and the outer shell electron

options.label: D
options.text: Interaction of the high energy incident photon and the outer shell electron

questions.correct_answer: A. Interaction between low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Interaction between low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The photoelectric effect in diagnostic radiography can be defined as the interaction between a low-energy incident photon and an inner shell electron , leading to the ejection of the electron and subsequent emission of characteristic radiation , crucial for creating image contrast.
  • ➤ photoelectric effect
  • ➤ diagnostic radiography
  • ➤ defined as the interaction between a low-energy incident photon
  • ➤ inner shell electron
  • ➤ ejection of the electron
  • ➤ emission of characteristic radiation
  • ➤ creating image contrast.
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 222
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 222

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement about CT?

options.label: B
options.text: The higher the pitch, the lower will be the CT quality

options.label: C
options.text: Helical CT is faster than non-helical CT

options.label: D
options.text: The higher the pitch, the higher will be the radiation dose

questions.correct_answer: D. The higher the pitch, the higher will be the radiation dose
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Higher the pitch, the higher will be the radiation dose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. MDCT offers a better 3D reconstruction. Multidetector CT (MDCT) allows for faster data acquisition and finer spatial resolution , facilitating superior 3D reconstruction of images.
  • • Option A. MDCT offers a better 3D reconstruction.
  • • faster data acquisition and finer spatial resolution
  • • Option B. The higher the pitch, the lower will be the CT quality. Increasing the pitch , which refers to the table movement speed relative to the X-ray beam's width , an lead to decreased image quality due to potential artifacts and increased noise.
  • • Option B. The higher the pitch, the lower will be the CT quality.
  • • Increasing the pitch
  • • table movement speed relative to the X-ray beam's width
  • • Option C. Helical CT is faster than non-helical CT. Helical (spiral) CT uses continuous data acquisition as the patient moves through the scanner, leading to quicker scans compared to the step-and-shoot approach of non-helical CT.
  • • Option C. Helical CT is faster than non-helical CT.
  • • continuous data acquisition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ A higher pitch in CT scanning correlates with a faster table movement and typically results in a lower radiation dose to the patient, contrary to the notion that it increases dose exposure .
  • ➤ higher pitch in CT scanning
  • ➤ faster table movement
  • ➤ lower radiation dose
  • ➤ contrary to the notion
  • ➤ increases dose exposure
  • ➤ Figure 1 CT Scanner
  • ➤ Figure
  • ➤ 1
  • ➤ CT Scanner
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 928
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 928

questions.text: What is the appearance of CSF on T1 weight MRI-T2 weighted MRI -FLAIR respectively?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hypointense -Hyperintense-Hypointense

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • MRI sequences are essential tools for distinguishing between different types of tissue based on their appearance under various imaging conditions:
  • • MRI sequences
  • • distinguishing between different types of tissue
  • • T1-weighted images: CSF appears hypointense (dark) compared to the brain parenchyma . White matter appears hyperintense (bright) relative to gray matter. T2-weighted images: CSF appears hyperintense (bright) as it contains a high amount of water . Conversely, white matter appears hypointense compared to gray matter. FLAIR (Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery): CSF signal is suppressed , making it appear hypointense (dark), which helps to detect lesions , such as those caused by demyelination , edema , or infarction , which may appear hyperintense (bright).
  • • T1-weighted images: CSF appears hypointense (dark) compared to the brain parenchyma . White matter appears hyperintense (bright) relative to gray matter.
  • • T1-weighted images:
  • • CSF
  • • hypointense
  • • brain parenchyma
  • • T2-weighted images: CSF appears hyperintense (bright) as it contains a high amount of water . Conversely, white matter appears hypointense compared to gray matter.
  • • T2-weighted images:
  • • CSF
  • • hyperintense
  • • high amount of water
  • • FLAIR (Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery): CSF signal is suppressed , making it appear hypointense (dark), which helps to detect lesions , such as those caused by demyelination , edema , or infarction , which may appear hyperintense (bright).
  • • FLAIR (Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery):
  • • CSF signal
  • • suppressed
  • • hypointense
  • • detect lesions
  • • demyelination
  • • edema
  • • infarction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the signal characteristics of CSF across different MRI sequences is fundamental for interpreting brain images . CSF is typically dark on T1-weighted images , bright on T2-weighted images , and dark again on FLAIR images due to the suppression of the fluid signal to better detect pathology.
  • ➤ signal characteristics of CSF
  • ➤ different MRI sequences
  • ➤ fundamental
  • ➤ brain images
  • ➤ CSF
  • ➤ dark on T1-weighted images
  • ➤ bright
  • ➤ T2-weighted images
  • ➤ MRI SEQUENCES
  • ➤ MRI SEQUENCES

questions.text: What medical conditions are associated with posterior acoustic shadowing in ultrasound imaging? Air Bone Renal stones Uterine fibroids
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.  1,2,3,4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Posterior acoustic shadowing refers to the dark area that appears behind an object in an ultrasound image . This shadow is created when the sound waves produced by the ultrasound machine are blocked or absorbed by an object , such as a dense tissue or a calcification , and cannot pass through it.
  • • Posterior acoustic shadowing
  • • dark area
  • • appears behind an object
  • • ultrasound image
  • • shadow is created
  • • sound waves produced by the ultrasound machine
  • • blocked or absorbed by an object
  • • dense tissue
  • • calcification
  • • Includes air, bone, renal stones, and uterine fibroids . All these elements can cause posterior acoustic shadowing due to their high density or composition , which prevents ultrasound waves from passing through, casting a shadow on the image.
  • • air, bone, renal stones, and uterine fibroids
  • • elements
  • • posterior acoustic shadowing
  • • high density
  • • composition
  • • prevents ultrasound waves

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior acoustic shadowing is observed in the presence of air, bone, renal stones , and uterine fibroids as they are highly reflective or absorbent to ultrasound waves , preventing wave transmission and resulting in a shadow on the ultrasound image.
  • ➤ Posterior acoustic shadowing
  • ➤ presence of air, bone, renal stones
  • ➤ uterine fibroids
  • ➤ highly reflective
  • ➤ absorbent
  • ➤ ultrasound waves
  • ➤ Ref : Page no-445, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Page no-445, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: Identify the radiological procedure shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Enteroclysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Proctography: A radiological test that assesses the rectal and anal function during defecation .
  • • Option B. Proctography:
  • • radiological test
  • • rectal
  • • anal function
  • • defecation
  • • Option C. Barium enema: A barium contrast study of the large intestine that does not involve the small intestine as primarily visualized in the image.
  • • Option C. Barium enema:
  • • barium contrast study
  • • large intestine
  • • Option D. Barium meal follow-through: Involves oral ingestion of barium followed by sequential X-ray imaging to track its passage through the gastrointestinal tract.
  • • Option D. Barium meal follow-through:
  • • oral ingestion
  • • barium
  • • sequential X-ray imaging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image is characteristic of enteroclysis , where a tube is inserted up to the duodenojejunal flexure , and barium is injected to provide enhanced distension and visualization of the small bowel .
  • ➤ enteroclysis
  • ➤ tube is inserted up to the duodenojejunal flexure
  • ➤ barium
  • ➤ injected
  • ➤ enhanced distension
  • ➤ visualization
  • ➤ small bowel
  • ➤ Barium enteroclysis is performed via a tube inserted up to DJ flexure and barium is injected to provide better distension .
  • ➤ Barium enteroclysis
  • ➤ tube inserted up to DJ flexure
  • ➤ barium
  • ➤ injected
  • ➤ distension
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-276, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-276, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, distention, and fever. He reports having bloody diarrhea and has been using mesalamine and prednisone to manage his condition. On physical examination, his abdomen is tender and distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory tests indicate leukocytosis and electrolyte imbalances. An erect abdominal X-ray was taken as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Toxic megacolon

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Pneumatosis intestinalis involves the presence of gas cysts in the bowel wall , which is not indicated in this X-ray.
  • • Option A:
  • • Pneumatosis intestinalis
  • • presence of gas cysts
  • • bowel wall
  • • Option B: Perforation peritonitis would show free air under the diaphragm , which is not visible here.
  • • Option B:
  • • Perforation peritonitis
  • • free air under the diaphragm
  • • Option C: Diverticulitis typically presents with localized colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat stranding .
  • • Option C:
  • • Diverticulitis
  • • localized colonic wall thickening
  • • pericolic fat stranding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic radiographic findings of dilated colon segments and clinical symptoms suggest toxic megacolon , especially in a patient with a history of inflammatory bowel disease .
  • ➤ radiographic findings
  • ➤ dilated colon segments
  • ➤ toxic megacolon
  • ➤ inflammatory bowel disease
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-292, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-292, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and distension. She reports that she has been experiencing these symptoms for the past few months, but they have recently become more severe. On examination, her abdomen is distended, and a palpable mass is felt in the right upper quadrant. Her laboratory investigations show an elevated eosinophil count. USG is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Hydatid cyst

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pyogenic abscess: Usually presents as an irregular, poorly-defined hypoechoic or anechoic area on ultrasound , often with debris . It may also demonstrate posterior acoustic enhancement due to the liquefactive nature of the abscess . However, the presence of elevated eosinophils is less common in bacterial infections and more characteristic of parasitic infestations.
  • • Option A. Pyogenic abscess:
  • • irregular, poorly-defined hypoechoic
  • • anechoic area
  • • ultrasound
  • • debris
  • • posterior acoustic enhancement
  • • liquefactive nature of the abscess
  • • Option B. Hemangioma: Typically appears on ultrasound as a well-circumscribed, hyperechoic (bright) lesion due to its vascular nature . It does not typically present with elevated eosinophils or cause significant symptoms unless complicated.
  • • Option B. Hemangioma:
  • • well-circumscribed, hyperechoic
  • • vascular nature
  • • Option C. Amoebic abscess : Can present with symptoms similar to those described for the patient, and may show an elevated white blood cell count , often without a significant eosinophilia . On imaging, an amoebic abscess usually appears as a round or oval, hypoechoic lesion without internal structures.
  • • Option C. Amoebic abscess
  • • elevated white blood cell count
  • • without
  • • eosinophilia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient present with chronic abdominal pain , a palpable mass with elevated eosinophils , and ultrasound shows a multiloculated cystic structure , hydatid disease should be considered, particularly in areas where Echinococcus is endemic .
  • ➤ chronic abdominal pain
  • ➤ palpable mass
  • ➤ elevated eosinophils
  • ➤ ultrasound
  • ➤ multiloculated cystic structure
  • ➤ hydatid disease
  • ➤ Echinococcus is endemic
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 340
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 340
  • ➤ Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)
  • ➤ Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A primigravida with 18 weeks POG presents to the clinic for an anomaly scan. Oligohydramnios is noted with bladder shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Posterior urethral valves

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD) : This is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys . In utero , enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts might be visualized . It does not typically present with a "keyhole sign" on ultrasound.
  • • Option A.
  • • Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD)
  • • genetic disorder
  • • growth of numerous cysts
  • • kidneys
  • • utero
  • • enlarged kidneys
  • • multiple cysts
  • • visualized
  • • Simple renal cysts will appear anechoic with well-defined thin walls , posterior acoustic enhancement
  • • Simple renal cysts
  • • anechoic with well-defined thin walls
  • • posterior acoustic enhancement
  • • Option B. Hydronephrosis : This condition involves the swelling of one kidney due to a buildup of urine . It occurs when urine cannot drain from the kidney to the bladder from a blockage or obstruction . Sonographically, it would show as an enlargement of the renal pelvis and calyces and not a "keyhole sign."
  • • Option B.
  • • Hydronephrosis
  • • swelling of one kidney
  • • buildup of urine
  • • urine
  • • cannot drain from the kidney
  • • bladder
  • • blockage or obstruction
  • • Hydronephrosis : dilated pelvicalyceal system
  • • Hydronephrosis
  • • Option C. Chronic Pyelonephritis : This is a long-standing infection that leads to scarring and deformation of the kidney . Chronic pyelonephritis would show irregular, echogenic kidneys on ultrasound, which is not consistent with the provided sonographic image.
  • • Option C.
  • • Chronic Pyelonephritis
  • • long-standing infection
  • • leads to scarring
  • • deformation of the kidney
  • • Chronic Pyelonephritis: Irregular and heterogeneous echotexture of renal parenchyma
  • • Chronic Pyelonephritis: Irregular and heterogeneous echotexture of renal parenchyma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The keyhole sign is an ultrasonographic sign seen in boys with posterior urethral valves . It refers to the appearance of the proximal urethra (which is dilated) and associated thick-walled distended bladder which on ultrasound may resemble a key hole.
  • ➤ keyhole sign
  • ➤ ultrasonographic
  • ➤ boys with posterior urethral valves
  • ➤ appearance of the proximal urethra
  • ➤ thick-walled distended bladder
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 466
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 466

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic sinusitis. Despite appropriate medical therapy, her symptoms persist. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the paranasal sinuses is performed, and an abnormal finding is noted in the sinonasal anatomy. Identify the following structure marked with white arrow:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Haller Cell: These are ethmoidal air cells that are located along the inferomedial orbital floor , also known as infraorbital ethmoidal air cells . When enlarged, Haller cells can impinge on the maxillary sinus ostium and contribute to recurrent sinus infections.
  • • Option B. Haller Cell:
  • • ethmoidal air cells
  • • located along the inferomedial orbital floor
  • • infraorbital ethmoidal air cells
  • • Option C. Bulla Ethmoidalis: This is the largest and most constant of the anterior ethmoid air cells . It forms part of the lateral nasal wall and its enlargement can narrow the ethmoidal infundibulum, potentially causing obstruction of the osteomeatal complex, leading to sinusitis.
  • • Option C. Bulla Ethmoidalis:
  • • largest
  • • most constant
  • • anterior ethmoid air cells
  • • forms part of the lateral nasal wall
  • • Option D. Pneumatized Superior Turbinate: Rarely, the superior turbinate can become pneumatized . This condition is less commonly associated with sinusitis compared to the other anatomical variations.
  • • Option D. Pneumatized Superior Turbinate:
  • • superior turbinate
  • • become pneumatized

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Concha bullosa refers to the pneumatization of the middle turbinate and is a common variation that can sometimes obstruct sinus drainage , thereby contributing to chronic sinusitis.
  • ➤ Concha bullosa
  • ➤ pneumatization
  • ➤ middle turbinate
  • ➤ common variation
  • ➤ obstruct sinus drainage
  • ➤ chronic sinusitis.
  • ➤ Haller cells

References:

  • ↳ Reference
  • ↳ – Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 858

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath following a motor vehicle accident. On examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the left side. Bedside ultrasonography is performed, and the image shown is obtained using M-mode. Which of the following signs is most likely being depicted in this ultrasound image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Seashore sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Stratosphere sign : Also known as the barcode sign , this pattern is seen in M-mode when lung sliding is absent , such as in pneumothorax. It's characterized by parallel lines above and below the pleural line , resembling a barcode or a stratospheric pattern, without the sandy appearance of lung sliding.
  • • Option B. Stratosphere sign
  • • barcode sign
  • • M-mode
  • • lung sliding is absent
  • • pneumothorax.
  • • parallel lines above
  • • below the pleural line
  • • barcode
  • • Option C. Lung point sign : This sign is specific for pneumothorax in B-mode ultrasonography . It is the point at which the normal seashore sign and the abnormal stratosphere sign meet , indicating the presence of both lung tissue and the air of a pneumothorax side by side.
  • • Option C. Lung point sign
  • • pneumothorax in B-mode ultrasonography
  • • normal seashore sign
  • • abnormal stratosphere sign meet
  • • Option D. Sinusoidal sign : This sign is indicative of a 'flapping' motion of the heart or the IVC in M-mode and is typically associated with cardiac pathologies like pericardial effusion or exaggerated IVC collapsibility.
  • • Option D. Sinusoidal sign
  • • 'flapping' motion
  • • heart or the IVC in M-mode
  • • cardiac pathologies like pericardial effusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The seashore sign on M-mode ultrasonography is indicative of normal lung sliding , seen at the pleural lining due to relative motion between the two pleural layers . This is the M-mode counterpart of lung sliding seen in B-mode ultrasound, where motion of the lung deep to the pleura causes a grainy appearance, simulating the appearance of sand at a seashore.
  • ➤ seashore sign
  • ➤ M-mode ultrasonography
  • ➤ normal lung sliding
  • ➤ pleural lining
  • ➤ relative motion between the two pleural layers
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 14
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 14

questions.text: A woman presents for evaluation of infertility. Her physician has ordered a diagnostic imaging test . An image from the test is provided. What is the name of the investigation shown in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Conventional HSG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . MR HSG refers to magnetic resonance hysterosalpingography , which is not typically used in routine infertility evaluations due to its complexity and cost.
  • • Option A
  • • MR HSG
  • • magnetic resonance hysterosalpingography
  • • Option B. Falloscopy is an invasive tool to study the fallopian tubes.
  • • Option B. Falloscopy
  • • invasive tool
  • • Option D . USG HSG would imply ultrasound hysterosalpingography , a less common method that might use saline or contrast-enhanced fluid to visualize the uterus and fallopian tubes but does not provide as detailed an image as conventional HSG.
  • • Option D
  • • USG HSG
  • • ultrasound hysterosalpingography
  • • less common method
  • • use saline
  • • contrast-enhanced fluid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hysterosalpingography is a diagnostic radiological procedure that uses a contrast dye to visualize the uterus and fallopian tubes , often used in the evaluation of infertility .
  • ➤ Hysterosalpingography
  • ➤ diagnostic radiological procedure
  • ➤ contrast dye
  • ➤ visualize the uterus
  • ➤ fallopian tubes
  • ➤ evaluation of infertility
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 690
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 690

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient came to ER with the complaint of severe abdominal pain. CTA was performed which is given below. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: An abscess in the psoas muscle

questions.correct_answer: B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer: A ruptured gastric ulcer typically presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that may radiate to the back . On imaging, especially CT , we might see evidence of perforation with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum). This finding is not consistent with the provided CTA image.
  • • Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer:
  • • presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain
  • • radiate to the back
  • • especially CT
  • • perforation with free air
  • • diaphragm
  • • Option C. Acute appendicitis : Patients with acute appendicitis typically present with abdominal pain that begins around the navel and later localizes to the lower right abdomen , accompanied by fever and leukocytosis . A CTA would show an enlarged, inflamed appendix, potentially with an appendicolith (a calcified deposit), but no contrast extravasation outside the aorta as seen in the provided image.
  • • Option C. Acute appendicitis
  • • abdominal pain
  • • begins around the navel
  • • localizes to the lower right abdomen
  • • fever and leukocytosis
  • • enlarged, inflamed appendix,
  • • appendicolith
  • • Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle: A psoas abscess would typically present with flank pain , fever , and a palpable mass , or difficulty with movements that involve the psoas muscle . On CTA, an abscess may appear as a well-defined fluid collection with possible enhancement after contrast administration. Again, this does not match the findings in the CTA image provided.
  • • Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle:
  • • psoas abscess
  • • present with flank pain
  • • fever
  • • palpable mass
  • • difficulty with movements
  • • psoas muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The correct diagnosis is B - A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The provided CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta , indicative of extraluminal contrast from a ruptured aortic aneurysm . This is an urgent surgical emergency requiring immediate attention.
  • ➤ CTA shows a soft tissue density
  • ➤ contrast visible
  • ➤ outside
  • ➤ left side
  • ➤ abdominal aorta
  • ➤ extraluminal contrast
  • ➤ ruptured aortic aneurysm
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 200.
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 200.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of back pain and an abnormal curvature of the spine. Physical examination reveals a lateral curvature of the spine with a prominence of the left ribcage. The patient is otherwise healthy, with no other significant medical history. An X-ray of the spine is performed, which of the following angles would be measured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cobb angle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Bohler angle: The Bohler angle , or tuber joint angle , is used in orthopedics to assess calcaneal fractures on lateral foot radiographs . It is formed by the intersection of two lines : one drawn from the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus to the highest point of the posterior articular surface and the other from the highest point of the posterior articular surface to the highest point of the posterior aspect of the calcaneus.
  • • Option A. Bohler angle:
  • • Bohler angle
  • • tuber joint angle
  • • orthopedics
  • • assess calcaneal fractures
  • • lateral foot radiographs
  • • formed by the intersection
  • • two lines
  • • one drawn from the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus
  • • highest point of the posterior articular surface
  • • highest point of the posterior articular surface
  • • Option B. Gissane angle: Also known as the critical angle , it’s measured on lateral foot radiographs and used to assess calcaneal fractures , similar to the Bohler angle. It's formed by the downward and inward slopes of the calcaneus' superior surfaces.
  • • Option B. Gissane angle:
  • • critical angle
  • • measured on lateral foot radiographs
  • • assess calcaneal fractures
  • • Option D. Kite angle: This is used in pediatric orthopedics to assess the angular relationship between the talus and the first metatarsal in feet with flatfoot deformity on AP radiographs. It evaluates the congruence of the talonavicular joint.
  • • Option D. Kite angle:
  • • pediatric orthopedics
  • • assess the angular relationship
  • • talus
  • • first metatarsal in feet
  • • flatfoot deformity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Cobb angle is the correct parameter for quantifying the degree of scoliotic curves on spine radiographs , aiding in the diagnosis and management of scoliosis.
  • ➤ Cobb angle
  • ➤ correct parameter for quantifying the degree
  • ➤ scoliotic curves
  • ➤ spine radiographs
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 660
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 660

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes presents to the emergency department with chest pain that began approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest that radiates to his left arm. He also reports shortness of breath and nausea. On physical exam, his blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. The ECG shows ST-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin levels are elevated. What test can detect areas of reversible myocardial ischemia in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Thallium scan

Explanation:

  • • Explanations:
  • • Option A. Coronary angiography. Incorrect : It is an invasive test primarily used to define coronary anatomy and is not used to directly assess myocardial viability.
  • • Option A. Coronary angiography. Incorrect
  • • invasive test
  • • used to define coronary anatomy
  • • Option B. MUGA Scan. Incorrect : It is used to assess the pumping function of the ventricles but does not provide specific information on myocardial ischemia or infarction.
  • • Option B. MUGA Scan. Incorrect
  • • used to assess the pumping function
  • • ventricles
  • • Option D. Resting echocardiography. Incorrect: It can show wall motion abnormalities that suggest ischemia but may not differentiate between reversible and irreversible myocardial damage without the use of stress modalities.
  • • Option D. Resting echocardiography. Incorrect:
  • • show wall motion abnormalities
  • • ischemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thallium scan is used in diagnosing reversible myocardial ischemia . The scan involves imaging both at rest and during exercise or pharmacologic stress to visualize areas with reduced blood flow that may return to normal on rest imaging , indicating reversibility and the potential benefit from revascularization.
  • ➤ Thallium scan
  • ➤ used in diagnosing reversible myocardial ischemia
  • ➤ scan involves imaging
  • ➤ rest and during exercise
  • ➤ pharmacologic stress
  • ➤ visualize areas with reduced blood flow
  • ➤ return to normal on rest imaging
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 232
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 232

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of head and neck cancer treated with radiation therapy presents with persistent pain and exposed bone in the mandible, unresponsive to conservative management for several months. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Osteoradionecrosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A . Nausea : Nausea is a common early side effect of radiation therapy , particularly when the abdominal or pelvic regions are involved . It usually occurs within hours to days after treatment begins and can often be managed with antiemetic medications.
  • • Option A
  • • Nausea
  • • common early side effect of radiation therapy
  • • abdominal or pelvic regions are involved
  • • Option B. Erythema : Erythema refers to the reddening of the skin that can occur after radiation exposure . It is also an early side effect, similar to sunburn, and can appear within days to weeks of starting therapy. The severity of erythema varies and is typically self-limited.
  • • Option B.
  • • Erythema
  • • reddening of the skin
  • • after radiation exposure
  • • Option C. Anemia : Anemia can be both an early or late side effect of radiation therapy . Early on, it may be due to acute damage to the bone marrow, leading to decreased production of red blood cells. Late effects can be due to chronic bone marrow insufficiency or fibrosis, resulting in sustained reduced red blood cell production.
  • • Option C.
  • • Anemia
  • • both an early or late side effect of radiation therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteoradionecrosis is a significant late complication characterized by the death of bone tissue due to its reduced blood supply following radiation , leading to persistent pain , non-healing wounds , and bone exposure.
  • ➤ Osteoradionecrosis
  • ➤ late complication
  • ➤ death of bone tissue
  • ➤ reduced blood supply
  • ➤ radiation
  • ➤ persistent pain
  • ➤ non-healing wounds
  • ➤ bone exposure.
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 464
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 464

questions.text: In the imaging of the saphenofemoral junction, which sign represents the relationship between the femoral artery, femoral vein, and saphenous vein?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Mickey mouse sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Stemmer's sign: Stemmer's sign is a clinical sign used in the diagnosis of lymphedema ; it indicates the presence of non-pitting edema , where the skin cannot be easily lifted at the base of the second toe or finger.
  • • Option B. Stemmer's sign:
  • • diagnosis of lymphedema
  • • presence of non-pitting edema
  • • Option C. Tillaux sign: Tillaux sign is a clinical sign in orthopedics related to an avulsion fracture of the anterolateral tibial epiphysis in adolescents , not related to vascular structures.
  • • Option C. Tillaux sign:
  • • clinical sign in orthopedics
  • • avulsion fracture
  • • anterolateral tibial epiphysis
  • • adolescents
  • • Option D. String sign: The string sign is used to describe the appearance of a long , narrow constriction seen in conditions such as Crohn's disease or in imaging of arteries that are severely narrowed.
  • • Option D. String sign:
  • • appearance of a long
  • • narrow
  • • constriction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The "Mickey Mouse sign " on ultrasound is a descriptive term for the normal arrangement of the femoral vessels at the saphenofemoral junction , aiding in the identification and assessment of vascular structures in this area.
  • ➤ "Mickey Mouse sign
  • ➤ ultrasound
  • ➤ descriptive term
  • ➤ normal arrangement
  • ➤ femoral vessels
  • ➤ saphenofemoral junction
  • ➤ identification
  • ➤ assessment
  • ➤ vascular structures
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No

questions.text: Which radiographic view is best suited for visualizing pathologies of the middle lobe of the lung?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Lordotic view

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Left anterior oblique: This view can help visualize certain structures of the heart and lungs , but it is not the preferred view for middle lobe pathologies.
  • • Option A. Left anterior oblique:
  • • help visualize certain structures
  • • heart and lungs
  • • Option B. PA view: The posteroanterior (PA) view is the standard chest x-ray view , which provides a frontal image of the thorax but may not give the best visualization of the middle lobe due to overlying structures.
  • • Option B. PA view:
  • • posteroanterior
  • • view
  • • standard chest x-ray view
  • • frontal image of the thorax
  • • Option D. Oblique view: Oblique views are angled views that may assist in evaluating specific structures or lesions in the chest but are not specifically tailored to visualize the middle lobe compared to the lordotic view.
  • • Option D. Oblique view:
  • • angled views
  • • assist in evaluating specific structures
  • • lesions
  • • chest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lordotic view , or apical lordotic view , is the radiographic view of choice for evaluating pathologies of the middle lobe of the lung , as it allows a clearer visualization of this area by projecting the clavicles higher and out of the way .
  • ➤ lordotic view
  • ➤ apical lordotic view
  • ➤ radiographic view
  • ➤ middle lobe of the lung
  • ➤ allows a clearer visualization of this area
  • ➤ projecting the clavicles higher
  • ➤ out of the way
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 498
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 498

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of recurrent headaches and pulsatile tinnitus in her left ear. She has also noticed a throbbing sensation in her neck, especially on the left side. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg in the right arm and 160/100 mmHg in the left arm. There is a prominent bruit heard on auscultation over the left carotid artery. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD) should be considered in patients presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, headaches, and a carotid bruit, especially with differential blood pressure readings between arms. It is a non-inflammatory vascular disease affecting medium and large arteries, leading to stenosis, aneurysms, or dissections.
  • ➤ Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD) should be considered in patients presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, headaches, and a carotid bruit, especially with differential blood pressure readings between arms.
  • ➤ It is a non-inflammatory vascular disease affecting medium and large arteries, leading to stenosis, aneurysms, or dissections.

questions.text: A newborn present with treatment-resistant congestive heart failure, a bulging anterior fontanelle, a bruit upon auscultation, and a transfontanellar ultrasound as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vein of Galen malformation should be considered in neonates with resistant congestive heart failure, bulging fontanelle, and bruit on auscultation, especially if imaging reveals a midline mass with ventricular dilation. This vascular anomaly requires specific neurosurgical and medical intervention to manage the high-output cardiac failure and potential hydrocephalus.
  • ➤ Vein of Galen malformation should be considered in neonates with resistant congestive heart failure, bulging fontanelle, and bruit on auscultation, especially if imaging reveals a midline mass with ventricular dilation.
  • ➤ This vascular anomaly requires specific neurosurgical and medical intervention to manage the high-output cardiac failure and potential hydrocephalus.

questions.text: During an intravenous pyelogram, one kidney fails to appear on the imaging. Which condition is most likely to cause the nonvisualization of the kidney?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Renal hypoplasia is a condition where the kidney does not develop properly and may not function adequately to excrete contrast material used in the study, leading to nonvisualization.
  • ➤ Renal hypoplasia is a condition where the kidney does not develop properly and may not function adequately to excrete contrast material used in the study, leading to nonvisualization.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden, severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain is described as tearing in nature. His blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. A CT scan is performed and the image is provided below. Given the clinical history and radiographic findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient present with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, particularly with risk factors such as hypertension and a history of smoking, a thoracic aortic aneurysm should be highly suspected. CT imaging showing aortic dilation is critical for diagnosis and immediate management to prevent catastrophic outcomes like aortic rupture.
  • ➤ When a patient present with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, particularly with risk factors such as hypertension and a history of smoking, a thoracic aortic aneurysm should be highly suspected.
  • ➤ CT imaging showing aortic dilation is critical for diagnosis and immediate management to prevent catastrophic outcomes like aortic rupture.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with recurrent abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath and chest pain. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest. A chest X-ray is performed and shows abnormal findings. Given the patient's symptoms and the chest X-ray results, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chilaiditi syndrome involves the interposition of bowel loops between the liver and diaphragm and can mimic respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms. It's important to differentiate it from actual hernias as its management is less invasive and may not require surgical intervention unless symptomatic.
  • ➤ Chilaiditi syndrome involves the interposition of bowel loops between the liver and diaphragm and can mimic respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • ➤ It's important to differentiate it from actual hernias as its management is less invasive and may not require surgical intervention unless symptomatic.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with persistent headaches and a progressive decrease in hearing. She undergoes an MRI of the brain, which is shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral vestibular schwannomas seen on brain imaging are pathognomonic for Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2). NF2 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple central nervous system tumors, including bilateral vestibular schwannomas, which can lead to hearing loss and other neurological symptoms.
  • ➤ Bilateral vestibular schwannomas seen on brain imaging are pathognomonic for Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
  • ➤ NF2 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple central nervous system tumors, including bilateral vestibular schwannomas, which can lead to hearing loss and other neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, predominantly for solid foods over the past 6 months. He also reports significant unintentional weight loss during this period. A barium swallow study is performed, and the radiographic image is shown below. Based on these clinical findings and the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients presenting with progressive dysphagia, particularly when accompanied by unintentional weight loss, esophageal carcinoma should be considered as a likely diagnosis.
  • ➤ In patients presenting with progressive dysphagia, particularly when accompanied by unintentional weight loss, esophageal carcinoma should be considered as a likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agents is classified as an ionic monomer?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ionic monomer contrast agents, such as diatrizoate, have a higher osmolality due to their dissociation into ions in solution, leading to a greater risk of adverse reactions. In contrast, nonionic contrast agents, like iohexol and iodixanol, do not dissociate and have lower osmolality, making them safer for use in patients with a higher risk of contrast-induced complications.
  • ➤ Ionic monomer contrast agents, such as diatrizoate, have a higher osmolality due to their dissociation into ions in solution, leading to a greater risk of adverse reactions.
  • ➤ In contrast, nonionic contrast agents, like iohexol and iodixanol, do not dissociate and have lower osmolality, making them safer for use in patients with a higher risk of contrast-induced complications.

questions.text: An incidental finding was noted on a NCCT abdomen performed for suspected renal calculus. What would be the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cholecystectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct management for a porcelain gallbladder , characterized by gallbladder wall calcification and associated with an increased risk ofcancer, is prophylactic cholecystectomy.
  • ➤ The correct management for a porcelain gallbladder , characterized by gallbladder wall calcification and associated with an increased risk ofcancer, is prophylactic cholecystectomy.
  • ➤ porcelain gallbladder
  • ➤ gallbladder wall calcification
  • ➤ increased risk ofcancer,
  • ➤ prophylactic cholecystectomy.
  • ➤ This approach is to prevent the potential development of gallbladder carcinoma.
  • ➤ This approach is to prevent the potential development of gallbladder carcinoma.

questions.text: A radiology resident is reviewing a thyroid ultrasound for evaluation of a nodule. Which of the following is not included in the American College of Radiology's Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System (ACR TI-RADS) criteria?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vascularity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vascularity is not included in the ACR TI-RADS criteria for thyroid nodules. TI-RADS is utilized to stratify the risk of thyroid nodules based on their ultrasound characteristics , excluding vascularity , which aids medical students and residents in identifying nodules that may require further evaluation or intervention.
  • ➤ Vascularity is not included in the ACR TI-RADS criteria for thyroid nodules. TI-RADS is utilized to stratify the risk of thyroid nodules based on their ultrasound characteristics , excluding vascularity , which aids medical students and residents in identifying nodules that may require further evaluation or intervention.
  • ➤ Vascularity
  • ➤ ACR TI-RADS
  • ➤ thyroid nodules.
  • ➤ TI-RADS
  • ➤ utilized to stratify
  • ➤ thyroid nodules
  • ➤ ultrasound characteristics
  • ➤ vascularity

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed which revealed multiple rings enhancing lesions. MR spectroscopy showed a prominent lipid-lactate peak. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tuberculoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with headaches and altered sensorium , multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI , accompanied by a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy , are indicative of tuberculoma , where the lipid-lactate peak suggests necrosis within the lesions.
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with headaches and altered sensorium , multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI , accompanied by a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy , are indicative of tuberculoma , where the lipid-lactate peak suggests necrosis within the lesions.
  • ➤ patient presenting with headaches
  • ➤ altered sensorium
  • ➤ multiple ring-enhancing lesions
  • ➤ MRI
  • ➤ prominent lipid-lactate peak
  • ➤ MR spectroscopy
  • ➤ tuberculoma

questions.text: A 48-year-old female with a history of renal transplantation 4 months prior is being evaluated for renal function. Which imaging modality should be utilized for functional assessment of her transplanted kidney?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tc 99m MAG3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The most appropriate nuclear medicine imaging test to assess renal function in a patient who has undergone renal transplantation is Tc 99m MAG3 scan because it measures renal perfusion, function, and urinary excretion effectively in the post-transplant setting.
  • ➤ The most appropriate nuclear medicine imaging test to assess renal function in a patient who has undergone renal transplantation is Tc 99m MAG3 scan because it measures renal perfusion, function, and urinary excretion effectively in the post-transplant setting.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a low-grade fever, loss of appetite, and weight loss. A barium meal follow-through is performed and reveals abnormalities. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ileocecal TB is characterized by a narrowed terminal ileum, thickening of the ileocecal valve, and a "string sign" on barium meal follow-through, along with systemic symptoms like low-grade fever, loss of appetite, and weight loss.
  • ➤ Ileocecal TB is characterized by a narrowed terminal ileum, thickening of the ileocecal valve, and a "string sign" on barium meal follow-through, along with systemic symptoms like low-grade fever, loss of appetite, and weight loss.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the clinic with symptoms suggestive of portal hypertension. The physician suspects a change in portal venous flow and needs to determine the best investigation to detect hepatofugal flow. What is the best investigation to detect a change in portal venous flow to hepatofugal flow?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Color Doppler

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Color Doppler ultrasound is the best investigation to detect changes in portal venous flow, including the detection of hepatofugal flow, which is an early sign of portal hypertension.
  • ➤ Color Doppler ultrasound is the best investigation to detect changes in portal venous flow, including the detection of hepatofugal flow, which is an early sign of portal hypertension.

questions.text: A newborn presents with microcephaly, and imaging reveals calcifications at the gray matter-white matter junction. The physician suspects congenital Zika virus infection and needs to select the best imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis. What is the investigation of choice to detect congenital Zika virus infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NCCT is the preferred investigation for detecting calcifications in the brain, a key feature of congenital Zika virus infection, making it the best choice for confirming this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with progressive hearing loss and balance issues. Imaging reveals a mass in the cerebellopontine angle. The physician considers the differential diagnoses but needs to exclude one condition that is unlikely to present in this location. The differential diagnosis can include all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While meningiomas, acoustic schwannomas, and epidermoid cysts are common in the cerebellopontine angle, tuberculomas are rare in this location and are not typically included in the differential diagnosis.
  • ➤ While meningiomas, acoustic schwannomas, and epidermoid cysts are common in the cerebellopontine angle, tuberculomas are rare in this location and are not typically included in the differential diagnosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman who is breastfeeding her 3-month-old infant, presents to the clinic with a painful, red, and swollen lump in her right breast. She reports having fever and feeling unwell for the past 24 hours. On examination, there is a tender, fluctuant mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. What is the next best investigation to evaluate this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a lactating woman with a suspected breast abscess, ultrasound (USG) is the preferred initial investigation to evaluate the extent and nature of the mass and to guide any necessary procedures such as aspiration.
  • ➤ In a lactating woman with a suspected breast abscess, ultrasound (USG) is the preferred initial investigation to evaluate the extent and nature of the mass and to guide any necessary procedures such as aspiration.

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain presents to the emergency department. The patient is hypotensive, tachycardia, and appears to be in distress. A chest x-ray is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perforated peptic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray in a patient with acute severe abdominal pain, hypotension, and tachycardia is most indicative of a perforated peptic ulcer, leading to pneumoperitoneum and acute peritonitis.
  • ➤ The presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray in a patient with acute severe abdominal pain, hypotension, and tachycardia is most indicative of a perforated peptic ulcer, leading to pneumoperitoneum and acute peritonitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is diagnosed with a small brain tumor, and the treatment plan includes stereotactic radiosurgery. What type of treatment is stereotactic radiosurgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Stereotactic radiosurgery is a form of radiotherapy that delivers precise, high doses of radiation to a small area, such as a brain tumor, while sparing the surrounding healthy tissue.
  • ➤ Stereotactic radiosurgery is a form of radiotherapy that delivers precise, high doses of radiation to a small area, such as a brain tumor, while sparing the surrounding healthy tissue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive muscle weakness, particularly affecting the eyes and throat, leading to difficulty with swallowing and drooping eyelids. Imaging studies reveal a mediastinal mass. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thymoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thymoma is the most common anterior mediastinal mass associated with myasthenia gravis, presenting with symptoms like progressive muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and drooping eyelids.

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure in the image? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Midbrain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The midbrain is identified on MRI scans by anatomical structures including the red nuclei, substantia nigra, and the cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Intervertebral disc calcification is seen in the image suggestive of alkaptonuria.
  • • Deficiency: Homogentisic oxidase
  • • Hyperpigmentation of ears and eyes suggestive of ochronosis is a clue. It is seen due to excessive build-up of homogentisic acid.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): Features ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies, often with a "candle wax dripping" appearance, distinct from the findings in alkaptonuria.
  • • Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis):
  • • Option B. Fluorosis: Typically presents with increased bone density and ossification of interosseous ligaments, not specifically associated with hyperpigmentation or the disc calcifications shown.
  • • Option B. Fluorosis:
  • • Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Characterized by a "bamboo spine" appearance due to bony fusion, seen in younger patients (less than 50 years old), which does not typically include hyperpigmentation or the type of disc calcification seen in alkaptonuria.
  • • Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria - Is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic oxidase Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification DISH VS Ankylosing spondylitis
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria - Is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic oxidase
  • ➤ Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification
  • ➤ DISH VS Ankylosing spondylitis
  • ➤ DISH VS Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given X-ray finding seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Reflux esophagitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appearance of a feline esophagus on a barium swallow X-ray is indicative of eosinophilic esophagitis and is often associated with conditions like asthma and GERD. This finding underscores the importance of considering inflammatory and allergic contributions in patients presenting with esophageal symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Extradural Hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image demonstrates a right-sided hyperdense lesion, characteristic of an Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH). Features supporting this diagnosis include:
  • • Shape and Location: The lesion exhibits a biconvex or "lens-shaped" appearance, typically not crossing sutures, localized at the pterion which is a common site for EDH due to its proximity to the middle meningeal artery (MMA).
  • • Shape and Location:
  • • Type of Trauma : Associated with high-energy trauma such as a road traffic accident, often causing arterial bleeding, specifically from the MMA.
  • • Type of Trauma
  • • Lucid Interval: Patients may experience a lucid interval where symptoms improve temporarily before deteriorating, due to the building pressure from the accumulating blood.
  • • Lucid Interval:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH): Typically appears as a crescentic or "banana-shaped" collection that can cross sutures but not midline. It arises from bridging veins, often due to lower-energy trauma.
  • • Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH):
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Usually presents as diffuse or patchy areas of increased density in the subarachnoid spaces, not shown in the image.
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:
  • • Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Would be visualized within the ventricular system, which is not evident here.
  • • Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following will not be avid on FDG PET scan? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Typical carcinoid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Typical carcinoids generally do not show avid uptake on an FDG PET scan because they are well-differentiated tumors with relatively low metabolic activity compared to more aggressive cancers. FDG PET scans are most effective in identifying tumors that have high glucose metabolism, which is more characteristic of rapidly growing and less differentiated tumors. Typical carcinoids, being slow-growing, often exhibit minimal FDG uptake, making them less detectable on PET scans.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Small cell carcinoma : This type of cancer is highly aggressive and shows high metabolic activity, making it usually very avid on FDG PET scans.
  • • Option B. Small cell carcinoma
  • • Option C. Atypical carcinoid: More aggressive than typical carcinoids, often showing intermediate to high FDG uptake due to higher metabolic activity.
  • • Option C. Atypical carcinoid:
  • • Option D. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma : A highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that generally shows significant FDG uptake due to its rapid growth and high metabolic rate.
  • • Option D. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumors false-negative on PET-CT:
  • ➤ Tumors false-negative on PET-CT:
  • ➤ Lung adenocarcinoma
  • ➤ Mucinous adenocarcinoma
  • ➤ Typical carcinoid

questions.text: A 36-year-old animal handler came to the clinic with cough, chest pain for one week, and fatigue for a month. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hydatid cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with a history of exposure to animals and presenting with symptoms suggestive of a lung lesion, along with characteristic imaging findings of a cystic structure with a "Waterlily sign," hydatid cyst should be considered as a likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with fever and cough for 6 days. The CXR is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? ( FMGE June 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Right middle lobe consolidation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Silhouette sign is to be applied here. Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border . In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine. The outline of a specific structure that is created at the boundary between two tissues with varying tissue densities is called a silhouette in a chest radiograph, for example, the cardiac silhouette between the heart and the lung. The silhouette sign is the blurring or obliteration of these typical silhouettes brought on by disease pathologies.
  • • Silhouette sign is to be applied here. Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border . In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.
  • • Silhouette sign
  • • Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border
  • • In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.
  • • The outline of a specific structure that is created at the boundary between two tissues with varying tissue densities is called a silhouette in a chest radiograph, for example, the cardiac silhouette between the heart and the lung.
  • • The silhouette sign is the blurring or obliteration of these typical silhouettes brought on by disease pathologies.
  • • The silhouette sign is the blurring or obliteration of these typical silhouettes
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Right Lower Lobe Consolidation: Would more typically obscure the right diaphragm or show a basal shadowing in the posterior-anterior view.
  • • Option A. Right Lower Lobe Consolidation:
  • • Option B. Mitral Stenosis : Would not directly affect lung parenchyma; might lead to pulmonary congestion seen as diffuse bilateral shadowing.
  • • Option B. Mitral Stenosis
  • • Option D. Right Loculated Effusion: Typically appears as a denser, more fluid-like shadowing at the lung bases or along the pleural lining, often with a meniscus.
  • • Option D. Right Loculated Effusion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: A child presents with history of acute dysphagia. CXR is shown below. What is the next best step? (AIIMS 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: Reassure and to check whether passed in stools

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Remove endoscopically

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given CXR shows a foreign body in the esophagus which is likely to be a button battery as seen by the double margins.
  • • In profile/ en face: Foreign body is in the esophagus
  • • The next step should be to endoscopically removing those batteries as they lead to tissue necrosis by liquefactive necrosis.
  • • Patient’s oral intake should be prohibited until the location of the foreign body is confirmed. Never induce vomiting in these patients as it can again lodge back in the esophagus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Remove with bronchoscopy: Bronchoscopy is not suitable as the foreign body is located in the esophagus, not the airways.
  • • Option A. Remove with bronchoscopy:
  • • Option C. Reassure and check whether passed in stools: This approach is inappropriate due to the urgent risk of tissue damage from the battery; immediate removal is necessary.
  • • Option C. Reassure and check whether passed in stools:
  • • Option D. Induce vomiting: Inducing vomiting is contraindicated as it can cause further esophageal injury or lead to re-lodgement of the battery in the esophagus.
  • • Option D. Induce vomiting:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected ingestion of button batteries as seen on CXR, urgent endoscopic removal is critical to prevent tissue damage and potential complications. Vomiting should never be induced in these situations as it can exacerbate the problem.
